Federated Learning with Lossy Distributed Source Coding: Analysis and Optimization

Huiyuan Yang, Tian Ding, Xiaojun Yuan This work has been submitted to the IEEE for possible publication. Copyright may be transferred without notice, after which this version may no longer be accessible.
Abstract

Recently, federated learning (FL), which replaces data sharing with model sharing, has emerged as an efficient and privacy-friendly machine learning (ML) paradigm. One of the main challenges in FL is the huge communication cost for model aggregation. Many compression/quantization schemes have been proposed to reduce the communication cost for model aggregation. However, the following question remains unanswered: What is the fundamental trade-off between the communication cost and the FL convergence performance? In this paper, we manage to answer this question. Specifically, we first put forth a general framework for model aggregation performance analysis based on the rate-distortion theory. Under the proposed analysis framework, we derive an inner bound of the rate-distortion region of model aggregation. We then conduct an FL convergence analysis to connect the aggregation distortion and the FL convergence performance. We formulate an aggregation distortion minimization problem to improve the FL convergence performance. Two algorithms are developed to solve the above problem. Numerical results on aggregation distortion, convergence performance, and communication cost demonstrate that the baseline model aggregation schemes still have great potential for further improvement.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, model aggregation, rate-distortion theory, distributed source coding, Berger-Tung coding, majorization-minimization.

I Introduction

Currently, there are nearly 6.3 billion smartphones [1] and more than 11.3 billion connected Internet of Things (IoT) devices [2] worldwide, which constantly collect/generate a wealth of data, such as videos, images, and measurements. In the conventional cloud-centric machine learning (ML) paradigm, all the training data is uploaded to a cloud server to produce effective inference models [3]. However, this centralized paradigm becomes unsatisfactory due to (i) the increasing sensitivity to data privacy and (ii) the increasing burden on the backbone network caused by the ever-growing data to be transmitted [4]. A decentralized ML paradigm called federated learning (FL) has been proposed to tackle these challenges. In FL, a number of user devices collaboratively train a global machine learning model with the help of a parameter server (PS). In each training iteration, the PS first broadcasts the parameters of the global model to some selected devices. Each selected device then computes a local update, e.g., a gradient vector based on its local dataset, and then transmit it to the PS. Subsequently, the PS aggregates the locally computed updates to acquire a global update. Finally, FL updates the parameters of the global model and proceeds to the next iteration. In this way, FL avoids direct data transmission and only requires exchanges of model parameters/updates, thereby reducing the overall communication cost without sacrificing data privacy. However, in each iteration, the selected user devices need to transmit their local updates to the PS, still entailing a significant volume of uplink transmission. Currently, the uplink communication cost appears to be a critical bottleneck in the employment of FL systems, especially for FL over wireless networks [5].

An interesting line of research to reduce the communication cost for FL over wireless networks is introducing the over-the-air computation (AirComp) technique into the FL uplink, referred to as over-the-air FL. In over-the-air FL, all selected user devices concurrently transmit their local updates using the same radio resource. By utilizing the signal superposition property of the multiple-access channel, AirComp has been shown to significantly relieve the communication bottleneck of FL [6, 7]. Nevertheless, over-the-air FL has some intractable deficiencies: (i) not directly deployable on current digital communication systems due to analog modulation; (ii) vulnerable to the stragglers [7]; (iii) difficult to combat the Byzantine attack effectively due to the uncoded nature [8]. Therefore, orthogonal FL uplink, where user devices are allocated with orthogonal resource units, is considered a more mature and practical setting by far.

There is also a growing body of research aiming to design communication-efficient FL systems with orthogonal uplink. For example, the authors of [9] proposed to select only part of the user devices to transmit their local updates. To save uplink communication resource, the selection is based on certain criteria such as link quality [10]. Some works also proposed to exploit the sparsity in local gradients [11, 12, 13]. It was assumed that a portion of elements in local updates have very small magnitudes. These elements are considered negligible to the global model training, hence not being transmitted to the PS. The above schemes discard either a portion of local updates or a portion of elements in local updates. Such a coarse-grained discarding strategy could easily leave out exploitable information, potentially leading to a deterioration of the learning performance.

Another popular approach to reduce the FL uplink cost is to adopt techniques of compression and/or quantization [14, 15, 16, 17, 18]. For example, the authors in [14] suggested to only transmit the signs of elements in the local updates, so as to reduce the payload of the uplink transmission. In [15, 16, 17], various random scalar quantization methods are used to compress the local updates. The authors in [18] further proposed a lattice-based vector quantization scheme.

In the above works for orthogonal FL uplink, the local updates from different user devices are treated as samples from independent information sources. The local updates are separately transmitted to the PS via orthogonal channels. Based on the received signals, the PS first decodes all the local updates independently, and then aggregates them to generate the global model update. However, it was observed that the local updates are not independent in practical machine learning tasks but possess a significant correlation among user devices [19, 20]. This correlation, if properly utilized, can potentially reduce a great amount of communication cost for model aggregation. Furthermore, the PS does not have to estimate all the local updates but only the global update, which is a function of the local updates. Naturally, we have the following question: What is the performance limit of federated learning, especially when the adopted model aggregation scheme takes full advantage of the above two properties?

In this paper, we manage to answer the above question. The main contributions are listed as follows:

  • •

    We put forth a general information-theoretic analysis framework for the analysis of the model aggregation performance. In this analysis framework, the encoding, transmission, and aggregation (decoding) of the local updates are unified as a lossy distributed source coding (DSC) problem [21, 22, 23, 24, 25].

  • •

    Under the proposed analysis framework, we derive an inner bound of the rate-distortion region of model aggregation by giving an achievability scheme.

  • •

    We conduct an FL convergence analysis to characterize the relationship between the FL convergence performance and the aggregate distortion. We further develop two algorithms (for general and symmetric FL systems, respectively) to search for the point with minimum aggregation distortion in our proposed inner region.

Numerical results are provided to evaluate the performance gap between baseline model aggregation schemes and our theoretical bound in terms of aggregation distortion, convergence performance, and communication cost. The results demonstrate that the baseline model aggregation schemes still have great potential for further improvement in the considered scenarios.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we introduce the FL system and formulate a framework for aggregation performance analysis. In Section III, we derive an inner bound of the rate-distortion region of model aggregation. Sections IV and V develop two algorithms to minimize the aggregation distortion for general and symmetric FL systems, respectively. In Section VI, we present the numerical results. Finally, conclusions are drawn in Section VII.

II System Model and Aggregation Performance Analysis Framework

II-A Federated Learning System

We consider a federated learning (FL) system comprising a central parameter server (PS) and M𝑀M distributed user devices. The objective of the FL system is to cooperatively train a global machine learning model (parameterized by vector 𝜽∈ℝN𝜽superscriptℝ𝑁\boldsymbol{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{N}) based on the data collected by the user devices. Specifically, in FL, each device m𝑚m is only allowed to access its local dataset 𝒟m={𝜻m,k}k=1Kmsubscript𝒟𝑚superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜻𝑚𝑘𝑘1subscript𝐾𝑚\mathcal{D}_{m}=\{\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{m,k}\}_{k=1}^{K_{m}}, where Kmsubscript𝐾𝑚K_{m} is the sample size and 𝜻m,ksubscript𝜻𝑚𝑘\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{m,k} is the k𝑘k-th training sample collected by device m𝑚m111For example, in supervised learning each training sample 𝜻m,ksubscript𝜻𝑚𝑘\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{m,k} consists of a feature vector and a corresponding label.. For each device m𝑚m, we define a local empirical loss function with respect to the global model parameter 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}, given by

Lm​(𝜽;𝒟m)≜1Km​∑k=1Kml​(𝜽;𝜻m,k),≜subscript𝐿𝑚𝜽subscript𝒟𝑚1subscript𝐾𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑘1subscript𝐾𝑚𝑙𝜽subscript𝜻𝑚𝑘L_{m}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}_{m})\triangleq\frac{1}{K_{m}}\sum_{k=1}^{K_{m}}l(\boldsymbol{\theta};\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{m,k}), (1)

where l​(𝜽;𝜻m,k)𝑙𝜽subscript𝜻𝑚𝑘l(\boldsymbol{\theta};\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{m,k}) denotes the sample-wise loss function. FL aims to minimize the global empirical loss function, i.e.,

min𝜽⁡L​(𝜽)≜1K​∑m=1MKm​Lm​(𝜽;𝒟m),≜subscript𝜽𝐿𝜽1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝐾𝑚subscript𝐿𝑚𝜽subscript𝒟𝑚\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}L(\boldsymbol{\theta})\triangleq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{m=1}^{M}K_{m}L_{m}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}_{m}), (2)

where K=∑m=1MKm𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝐾𝑚K=\sum_{m=1}^{M}K_{m} denotes the total sample size.

FL involves multiple rounds of iteration for convergence. At the t𝑡t-th iteration round, FL performs the following four steps:

  • (i)

    Model broadcast: The PS broadcasts the current global model parameter 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)} to all the devices.

  • (ii)

    Local update computation: Each device m𝑚m computes a local update 𝐠m(t)∈ℝNsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑚𝑡superscriptℝ𝑁\mathbf{g}_{m}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{R}^{N} on the basis of the received 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)} and the local dataset 𝒟msubscript𝒟𝑚\mathcal{D}_{m}.

  • (iii)

    Model Aggregation:

    • –

      Encoding: Each device m𝑚m properly encodes its local update 𝐠m(t)superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑚𝑡\mathbf{g}_{m}^{(t)} into codewords.

    • –

      Transmission: Each device m𝑚m transmits its messages to the PS via a bit-constrained error-free link [26, 15, 18].222In this paper, we do not restrict the communication links to be wired or wireless, but only requires them to be independent/orthogonal without interfering with each other.

    • –

      Decoding: After the PS receives all the codewords, it performs joint decoding to obtain 𝐠^(t)superscript^𝐠𝑡\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{(t)}, which is an estimation of global update 𝐠(t)superscript𝐠𝑡\mathbf{g}^{(t)}.333Since the transmission links from the user devices to the PS are bit-constrained and thus can not transmit continuous-valued local updates losslessly, the PS ends up with only an estimation of 𝐠(t)superscript𝐠𝑡\mathbf{g}^{(t)}. The global update 𝐠(t)superscript𝐠𝑡\mathbf{g}^{(t)} is a function of the local updates, denoted by

      𝐠(t)≜κ​(𝐠1(t),…,𝐠M(t)),≜superscript𝐠𝑡𝜅superscriptsubscript𝐠1𝑡…superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑀𝑡\mathbf{g}^{(t)}\triangleq\kappa\left(\mathbf{g}_{1}^{(t)},\dots,\mathbf{g}_{M}^{(t)}\right), (3)

      where κ:ℝ×⋯×ℝ⏟M↦ℝ:𝜅maps-tosubscript⏟ℝ⋯ℝ𝑀ℝ\kappa:\underbrace{\mathbb{R}\times\dots\times\mathbb{R}}_{M}\mapsto\mathbb{R} is the aggregation target function and is applied element-wise to the M𝑀M local updates in (3).444A more general way is to define the aggregation target function as a vectors-to-vector mapping. However, this broader definition might cause unnecessary difficulty in understanding. Thus, we use an element-wise function here.

  • (iv)

    Global model update: The PS updates the global model by 𝐠^(t)superscript^𝐠𝑡\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{(t)} with a learning rate η𝜂\eta, i.e., 𝜽(t+1)=𝜽(t)−η​𝐠^(t)superscript𝜽𝑡1superscript𝜽𝑡𝜂superscript^𝐠𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t+1)}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}-\eta\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{(t)}.

II-B Analysis Framework for Model Aggregation Performance

In this subsection, we propose an analysis framework for model aggregation performance from a rate-distortion theory perspective [21, 22, 23, 24, 25]. We consider the M𝑀M N𝑁N-dimensional local updates at the t𝑡t-th round to be M𝑀M vectors randomly generated from a joint distribution 𝒫N(t)subscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑡𝑁\mathcal{P}^{(t)}_{N}, i.e.,

(𝐠1(t),𝐠2(t),⋯,𝐠M(t))∼𝒫N(t).similar-tosubscriptsuperscript𝐠𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝐠𝑡2⋯subscriptsuperscript𝐠𝑡𝑀subscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑡𝑁\left(\mathbf{g}^{(t)}_{1},\mathbf{g}^{(t)}_{2},\cdots,\mathbf{g}^{(t)}_{M}\right)\sim\mathcal{P}^{(t)}_{N}. (4)

We emphasize that the elements in each 𝐠m(t)subscriptsuperscript𝐠𝑡𝑚\mathbf{g}^{(t)}_{m} are not necessarily independently or identically distributed. In the following, we focus on an arbitrary iteration round t𝑡t and omit the superscript (t)𝑡(t) for brevity whenever causing no ambiguity. We further add a superscript of N𝑁N to clarify the model dimension, i.e., denoting the local update by 𝐠mNsubscriptsuperscript𝐠𝑁𝑚\mathbf{g}^{N}_{m}, ∀m∈[M]for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\forall m\in[M].

We now introduce the performance analysis framework for the model aggregation step. First, each user device employs an encoder

that maps its local update to a positive integer bmN=fmN​(𝐠mN)subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑁𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑁𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝐠𝑁𝑚b^{N}_{m}=f^{N}_{m}(\mathbf{g}^{N}_{m}) and transmits bmNsubscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑁𝑚b^{N}_{m} to the PS. Upon receiving the codewords {bmN}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑁𝑚𝑚1𝑀\{b^{N}_{m}\}_{m=1}^{M}, the PS employs a joint decoder

to generate 𝐠^N=ψN​(b1N,⋯,bmN)superscript^𝐠𝑁superscript𝜓𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝑁⋯superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑚𝑁\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{N}=\psi^{N}(b_{1}^{N},\cdots,b_{m}^{N}), which is an estimation of the global update 𝐠N=κ​(𝐠1N,…,𝐠MN)superscript𝐠𝑁𝜅superscriptsubscript𝐠1𝑁…superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑀𝑁\mathbf{g}^{N}=\kappa(\mathbf{g}_{1}^{N},\dots,\mathbf{g}_{M}^{N}). Let d:ℝN×ℝN↦ℝ+:𝑑maps-tosuperscriptℝ𝑁superscriptℝ𝑁subscriptℝd:\mathbb{R}^{N}\times\mathbb{R}^{N}\mapsto\mathbb{R}_{+} be a distortion measure between two N𝑁N-dimensional vectors. Then, we have the following definition:

Definition 1.

A rate-distortion tuple (R1,…,RM,D)subscript𝑅1…subscript𝑅𝑀𝐷(R_{1},\dots,R_{M},D) is said to be achievable if for any ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 and any sufficiently large N𝑁N, there exists M𝑀M encoders {fmN}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑚𝑁𝑚1𝑀\{f_{m}^{N}\}_{m=1}^{M} and a joint decoder ψNsuperscript𝜓𝑁\psi^{N} such that rate 1N​log⁡(BmN)≤Rm+ϵ1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑚𝑁subscript𝑅𝑚italic-ϵ\displaystyle{\frac{1}{N}}\log\left(B_{m}^{N}\right)\leq R_{m}+\epsilon, ∀m∈[M]for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\forall m\in[M], and expected aggregation distortion 𝔼​[d​(𝐠N,𝐠^N)]≤D+ϵ𝔼delimited-[]𝑑superscript𝐠𝑁superscript^𝐠𝑁𝐷italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}[d(\mathbf{g}^{N},\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{N})]\leq D+\epsilon.

Loosely speaking, if a rate-distortion tuple (R1,⋯,RM,D)subscript𝑅1⋯subscript𝑅𝑀𝐷(R_{1},\cdots,R_{M},D) is proved to be achievable, then, as the model dimension N𝑁N increases, the expected aggregation distortion 𝔼​[d​(𝐠N,𝐠^N)]𝔼delimited-[]𝑑superscript𝐠𝑁superscript^𝐠𝑁\mathbb{E}[d(\mathbf{g}^{N},\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{N})] can be less than and arbitrarily close to D𝐷D with the rate log⁡(BmN)/Nsuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑚𝑁𝑁\log\left(B_{m}^{N}\right)/N less than and arbitrarily close to Rmsubscript𝑅𝑚R_{m}, ∀m∈[M]for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\forall m\in[M]. We also call Rmsubscript𝑅𝑚R_{m} and D𝐷D rate and distortion, respectively. The rate-distortion region of model aggregation is defined as the set of all achievable rate-distortion tuples, denoted by ℛ​𝒟⋆ℛsuperscript𝒟⋆\mathcal{RD}^{\star}. In the next section, we analyze the model aggregation performance by characterizing an inner bound of ℛ​𝒟⋆ℛsuperscript𝒟⋆\mathcal{RD}^{\star} under the quadratic distortion measure and the linear aggregation target function.

Remark 1.

Most of the model aggregation schemes in mainstream FL research [14, 15, 16, 17, 18] are covered by our analysis framework in Fig. 1.

Remark 2.

Our analysis framework for model aggregation performance is similar to the framework of the well-studied distributed function computation problem (please refer to [27, 23, 24, 28, 29] and references therein for further details). The main difference between them is that our framework allows the existence of correlations among the elements of the local updates, which better matches the application of FL (where the elements of the local updates are generally correlated [30, 20]). More specifically, we essentially model the FL model aggregation problem as a lossy compression problem for sources with memory rather than for memoryless sources considered in the distributed function computation problem. In the next section, to give a constructive analysis, we introduce some randomness (in the random rotation step) to break these element-wise correlations.

III An Inner Region of ℛ​𝒟⋆ℛsuperscript𝒟⋆\mathcal{RD}^{\star}

In this section, we give an achievability scheme, which characterizes an inner region of ℛ​𝒟⋆ℛsuperscript𝒟⋆\mathcal{RD}^{\star}, denoted by ℛ​𝒟inℛsubscript𝒟in\mathcal{RD}_{\mathrm{in}}. Following the common practice [18, 19, 20, 31], we consider a quadratic distortion measure d​(𝐠N,𝐠^N)=‖𝐠N−𝐠^N‖2/N𝑑superscript𝐠𝑁superscript^𝐠𝑁superscriptnormsuperscript𝐠𝑁superscript^𝐠𝑁2𝑁d(\mathbf{g}^{N},\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{N})=\|\mathbf{g}^{N}-\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{N}\|^{2}/N and a linear aggregation target function κ​(𝐠1N,…,𝐠MN)=∑m=1Mcm​𝐠mN𝜅subscriptsuperscript𝐠𝑁1…subscriptsuperscript𝐠𝑁𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑐𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝐠𝑁𝑚\kappa(\mathbf{g}^{N}_{1},\dots,\mathbf{g}^{N}_{M})=\sum_{m=1}^{M}c_{m}\mathbf{g}^{N}_{m}.

Fig. 2 summarizes the achievability scheme. First, the local update of each device m𝑚m is fed into the m𝑚m-th modified Berger-Tung encoder after pre-processing, and then each encoder encodes the preprocessed data into a codeword with rate Rmsubscript𝑅𝑚R_{m}. The modified Berger-Tung decoder performs joint decoding after receiving all the codewords, whose output is post-processed to obtain an estimation of the global update. In the remainder of this section, We first introduce the specific operations performed by each module in Fig. 2 and then characterize ℛ​𝒟inℛsubscript𝒟in\mathcal{RD}_{\mathrm{in}}.

III-A Data Processing

III-A1 Data pre-processing

The data pre-processing procedure consists of two steps: mean removal and random rotation. The main objective is to process the local updates so they can be modelled as samples from memoryless correlated Gaussian sources asymptotically.

In the mean removal step, Each device m𝑚m computes the average of the elements of 𝐠mNsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑚𝑁\mathbf{g}_{m}^{N} as g¯m=∑n=1N[𝐠mN]n/Nsubscript¯𝑔𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑚𝑁𝑛𝑁\bar{g}_{m}=\sum_{n=1}^{N}[\mathbf{g}_{m}^{N}]_{n}/N, which are then uploaded to the PS.555We assume that the cost of transmitting the scalars {g¯m}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑚1𝑀\{\bar{g}_{m}\}_{m=1}^{M} is negligible relative to that of transmitting the local updates. Subsequently, each device m𝑚m computes the mean-removed vector

𝐠~mN≜𝐠mN−g¯m​𝟏N.≜superscriptsubscript~𝐠𝑚𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑚𝑁subscript¯𝑔𝑚subscript1𝑁\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m}^{N}\triangleq\mathbf{g}_{m}^{N}-\bar{g}_{m}\mathbf{1}_{N}. (7)

In the random rotation step, the PS and all the devices generate a shared Haar distributed666That is, uniformly distributed on the set of orthogonal matrices. matrix 𝐀N∈ℝN×Nsuperscript𝐀𝑁superscriptℝ𝑁𝑁\mathbf{A}^{N}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times N} using public randomness. Each device m𝑚m computes

𝐱mN=𝐀N​𝐠~mN∈ℝN,∀m∈[M],formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑚𝑁superscript𝐀𝑁superscriptsubscript~𝐠𝑚𝑁superscriptℝ𝑁for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\mathbf{x}_{m}^{N}=\mathbf{A}^{N}\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m}^{N}\in\mathbb{R}^{N},\ \forall m\in[M], (8)

then feeds 𝐱mNsubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑁𝑚\mathbf{x}^{N}_{m} into the modified Berger-Tung encoder.

In the following, we show that, under certain assumptions on {𝐠mN}m=1Msubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐠𝑁𝑚𝑀𝑚1\{\mathbf{g}^{N}_{m}\}^{M}_{m=1}, the resulting {𝐱mN}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑚𝑁𝑚1𝑀\{\mathbf{x}_{m}^{N}\}_{m=1}^{M} can be asymptotically approximated by correlated Gaussian vectors in the sense of the quadratic distortion. We state the assumptions and the corresponding consequences as follows.

Assumption 1.

(Correlation model) The M𝑀M sequences of the mean-removed vectors {𝐠~mN∈ℝN}N∈ℤ+subscriptsuperscriptsubscript~𝐠𝑚𝑁superscriptℝ𝑁𝑁subscriptℤ\{\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m}^{N}\in\mathbb{R}^{N}\}_{N\in\mathbb{Z}_{+}}, m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M], can be modeled as 𝐠~mN=∑k=1Kem,k​𝐩kNsuperscriptsubscript~𝐠𝑚𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑒𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐩𝑘𝑁\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m}^{N}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}e_{m,k}\mathbf{p}_{k}^{N}, where each em,k∈ℝsubscript𝑒𝑚𝑘ℝe_{m,k}\in\mathbb{R} is a constant coefficient, and the base vectors {𝐩kN∈ℝN}N∈ℤ+subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐩𝑘𝑁superscriptℝ𝑁𝑁subscriptℤ\{\mathbf{p}_{k}^{N}\in\mathbb{R}^{N}\}_{N\in\mathbb{Z}_{+}}, k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K], are K𝐾K sequences of random vectors satisfying

  1. (i)

    {𝐩kN}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐩𝑘𝑁𝑘1𝐾\{\mathbf{p}_{k}^{N}\}_{k=1}^{K} are mutually independent, ∀N∈ℤ+for-all𝑁subscriptℤ\forall N\in\mathbb{Z}_{+};

  2. (ii)

    {𝐩kN}k=2Ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐩𝑘𝑁𝑘2𝐾\{\mathbf{p}_{k}^{N}\}_{k=2}^{K} are isotropically distributed777A random vector 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} is said to be isotropically distributed if, for any orthogonal matrix 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}, 𝐀𝐱𝐀𝐱\mathbf{A}\mathbf{x} and 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} have the same distribution., ∀N∈ℤ+for-all𝑁subscriptℤ\forall N\in\mathbb{Z}_{+};

  3. (iii)

    limN→∞‖𝐩kN‖22/N​=a.s.​τk2subscript→𝑁superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐩𝑘𝑁22𝑁a.s.superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑘2\lim_{N\rightarrow\infty}\|\mathbf{p}_{k}^{N}\|_{2}^{2}/N\overset{\text{a.s.}}{=}\tau_{k}^{2} for some τk>0subscript𝜏𝑘0\tau_{k}>0, ∀k∈[K]for-all𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\forall k\in[K];

Assumption 1 models the mean-removed local updates {𝐠~mN}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript~𝐠𝑚𝑁𝑚1𝑀\{\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m}^{N}\}_{m=1}^{M} as linear combinations of a group of random vectors {𝐩kN}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐩𝑘𝑁𝑘1𝐾\{\mathbf{p}_{k}^{N}\}_{k=1}^{K}. The correlation between local updates comes from their shared base vectors. We note that one of the base vectors, 𝐩1Nsuperscriptsubscript𝐩1𝑁\mathbf{p}_{1}^{N}, is allowed to be non-isotropic, and hence the mean-removed local updates {𝐠~mN}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript~𝐠𝑚𝑁𝑚1𝑀\{\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m}^{N}\}_{m=1}^{M} can possess a certain directional preference.

Remark 3.

We give the following justifications for Assumption 1:

  1. 1.

    Recall that the local empirical loss function is written as a linear combination of a group of mutually independent components (i.e., the sample-wise loss functions), where the randomness of these components comes from the randomness of the sample generation process. This linear combination property tends to be inherited in model updates, for example, when the model updates are gradients of the local empirical loss functions. This justifies our linear combination assumption to some extent.

  2. 2.

    In Assumption 1, all local updates are assumed to be weighted sums of the non-isotropic random vector 𝐩1Nsuperscriptsubscript𝐩1𝑁\mathbf{p}_{1}^{N} and some isotropic noise vectors {𝐩kN}k=2Ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐩𝑘𝑁𝑘2𝐾\{\mathbf{p}_{k}^{N}\}_{k=2}^{K}. That is, if a local update possesses a certain directional preference, this directional preference come only from the base vector 𝐩1Nsuperscriptsubscript𝐩1𝑁\mathbf{p}_{1}^{N}. This is consistent with a property of federated learning: every device hopes to update model parameters in the direction of the global update.

  3. 3.

    Assumption 1 allows the noises of local updates (i.e., {∑k=2Kem,k​𝐩kN}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑘2𝐾subscript𝑒𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐩𝑘𝑁𝑚1𝑀\{\sum_{k=2}^{K}e_{m,k}\mathbf{p}_{k}^{N}\}_{m=1}^{M}) to be correlated by sharing common base vectors. In practice, the correlated noises are originated from common sources of randomness during the data collection/measurement.

  4. 4.

    The well-known Gaussian Chief Executive Officer (CEO) model [32], which is often used to model correlations in distributed systems888The CEO model has been used to model the correlation between local updates in [31]., is included as a special case of Assumption 1. In Gaussian CEO, local updates are modeled as 𝐠~mN=𝐩1N+𝐩m+1Nsuperscriptsubscript~𝐠𝑚𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐩1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐩𝑚1𝑁\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m}^{N}=\mathbf{p}_{1}^{N}+\mathbf{p}_{m+1}^{N}, ∀m∈[M]for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\forall m\in[M], where {𝐩1N}∪{𝐩m+1N}m=1Msuperscriptsubscript𝐩1𝑁superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐩𝑚1𝑁𝑚1𝑀\{\mathbf{p}_{1}^{N}\}\cup\{\mathbf{p}_{m+1}^{N}\}_{m=1}^{M} are mutually independent random vectors with independent Gaussian elements. In our setting, 𝐩1Nsuperscriptsubscript𝐩1𝑁\mathbf{p}_{1}^{N} can be any random vector satisfying Assumptions 1-(i) and 1-(iii), which covers a much broader class of distributions than independent Gaussian. In particular, the elements of the local updates are generally correlated [30, 20]. Our model allows for such correlations, in contrast to the Gaussian CEO model.

III-A2 Data post-processing

III-B Modified Berger-Tung Coding

Under Assumption 1, sequence {[𝐱1N]n,…,[𝐱MN]n}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐱1𝑁𝑛…subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑀𝑁𝑛𝑛1𝑁\{[\mathbf{x}_{1}^{N}]_{n},\dots,[\mathbf{x}_{M}^{N}]_{n}\}_{n=1}^{N} can be asymptotically treated as N𝑁N samples from an M𝑀M-component memoryless Gaussian source (X1,…,XM)∼𝒩​(𝟎,𝚺X)similar-tosubscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑀𝒩0subscript𝚺𝑋(X_{1},\dots,X_{M})\sim\mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{0},\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}). Since the local updates are correlated [31, 19, 20], and only a function of the local updates needs to be recovered, we modify Berger-Tung coding to compress {𝐱mN}m=1Msubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑁𝑚𝑀𝑚1\{\mathbf{x}^{N}_{m}\}^{M}_{m=1}.

Berger-Tung coding, as the achievability scheme of the Berger-Tung inner bound [33, 34], is a well-known random coding technique that non-cooperatively compresses multiple correlated information sources. Loosely speaking, in Berger-Tung coding, M𝑀M correlated sources (X1,⋯,XM)subscript𝑋1⋯subscript𝑋𝑀(X_{1},\cdots,X_{M}) are encoded into codewords by M𝑀M separate encoders; based on the codewords, a joint decoder estimates all the sources {Xm}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑋𝑚𝑚1𝑀\{X_{m}\}_{m=1}^{M}; the estimation performance is evaluated using M𝑀M preset distortion measures.

However, in our application, the decoder only aims to estimate a function Y≜∑m=1Mcm​Xm≜𝑌superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑐𝑚subscript𝑋𝑚Y\triangleq\sum_{m=1}^{M}c_{m}X_{m} of the sources with quadratic distortion 𝔼​[(Y−Y^)2]𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑌^𝑌2\mathbb{E}[(Y-\hat{Y})^{2}], where Y^^𝑌\hat{Y} denotes the output of the decoder. To achieve this, we modify Berger-Tung coding by changing the constraints of codebook design to fit our application, i.e., changing the constraints from {𝔼​[(Xm−X^m)2]≤DB​T​C,m}m=1Msuperscriptsubscript𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑚subscript^𝑋𝑚2subscript𝐷𝐵𝑇𝐶𝑚𝑚1𝑀\{\mathbb{E}[(X_{m}-\hat{X}_{m})^{2}]\leq D_{BTC,m}\}_{m=1}^{M} to 𝔼​[(Y−Y^)2]≤DMBTC𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑌^𝑌2subscript𝐷MBTC\mathbb{E}[(Y-\hat{Y})^{2}]\leq D_{\text{MBTC}}.101010Please refer to [25, Chapter 12] for a detailed description. Following the achievability proof of the Berger-Tung inner bound10, any rate-distortion tuple in the following region can be achieved by our modified Berger-Tung coding (MBTC) scheme:

III-C The Inner Region ℛ​𝒟inℛsubscript𝒟in\mathcal{RD}_{\mathrm{in}}

Subsections III-A and III-B have introduced the achievability scheme in Fig. 2. In this subsection, we derive the inner region ℛ​𝒟inℛsubscript𝒟in\mathcal{RD}_{\text{in}}, a set of rate-distortion tuples that can be achieved using our proposed scheme.

Note that the expected aggregation distortion under our achievability scheme is given by

𝔼​[d​(𝐠N,𝐠^N)]=1N​𝔼​[‖∑m=1Mcm​𝐠mN−𝐠^N‖2]=(a)1N​𝔼​[‖∑m=1Mcm​𝐱mN−𝐱^N‖2],𝔼delimited-[]𝑑superscript𝐠𝑁superscript^𝐠𝑁1𝑁𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑐𝑚superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑚𝑁superscript^𝐠𝑁2superscript𝑎1𝑁𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑐𝑚superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑚𝑁superscript^𝐱𝑁2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[d(\mathbf{g}^{N},\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{N})]=\frac{1}{N}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\sum_{m=1}^{M}c_{m}\mathbf{g}_{m}^{N}-\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{N}\right\|^{2}\right]\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(a)}}{{=}}\frac{1}{N}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\sum_{m=1}^{M}c_{m}\mathbf{x}_{m}^{N}-\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{N}\right\|^{2}\right], (11)

where the equality (a𝑎a) follows from the orthogonality of matrix 𝐀Nsuperscript𝐀𝑁\mathbf{A}^{N}. The right-hand side of (11) happens to be the expected distortion of MBTC. Furthermore, from Fig. 2, the coding rates of MBTC are exactly the rates of our achievability scheme. Together, we make the following key observation: any rate-distortion tuple in ℛ​𝒟MBTCℛsubscript𝒟MBTC\mathcal{RD}_{\text{MBTC}} is numerically identical to a rate-distortion tuple in ℛ​𝒟inℛsubscript𝒟in\mathcal{RD}_{\text{in}} and vice versa. This yields ℛ​𝒟inℛsubscript𝒟in\mathcal{RD}_{\text{in}}, given by the following proposition.

Proposition 2.

Under Assumption 1, considering distortion measure d​(𝐚,𝐛)=‖𝐚−𝐛‖2/N𝑑𝐚𝐛superscriptnorm𝐚𝐛2𝑁d(\mathbf{a},\mathbf{b})=\|\mathbf{a}-\mathbf{b}\|^{2}/N with 𝐚,𝐛∈ℝN𝐚𝐛superscriptℝ𝑁\mathbf{a},\mathbf{b}\in\mathbb{R}^{N} and aggregation target function κ(a1,…,\kappa(a_{1},\dots, aM)=∑m=1Mcmama_{M})=\sum_{m=1}^{M}c_{m}a_{m}, an inner region of ℛ​𝒟⋆ℛsuperscript𝒟⋆\mathcal{RD}^{\star}, ℛ​𝒟inℛsubscript𝒟in\mathcal{RD}_{\mathrm{in}}, is given by

(ii)​∑m∈𝒮Rm≥I​(𝐱𝒮;𝐮𝒮∣𝐮𝒮c),∀𝒮⊂[M],𝒮≠Ø;formulae-sequenceiisubscript𝑚𝒮subscript𝑅𝑚𝐼superscript𝐱𝒮conditionalsuperscript𝐮𝒮superscript𝐮superscript𝒮𝑐formulae-sequencefor-all𝒮delimited-[]𝑀𝒮italic-Ø\displaystyle\mathrm{(ii)}\ \sum_{m\in\mathcal{S}}R_{m}\geq I\left(\mathbf{x}^{\mathcal{S}};\,\mathbf{u}^{\mathcal{S}}\mid\mathbf{u}^{\mathcal{S}^{c}}\right),\ \forall\mathcal{S}\subset[M],\ \mathcal{S}\neq\O;\

where Y^​(⋅)^𝑌⋅\hat{Y}(\cdot) is termed the reconstruction function, 𝐱≜[X1,…,XM]⊤≜𝐱superscriptsubscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑀top\mathbf{x}\triangleq[X_{1},\dots,X_{M}]^{\top}, 𝐮≜[U1,…,UM]⊤≜𝐮superscriptsubscript𝑈1…subscript𝑈𝑀top\mathbf{u}\triangleq[U_{1},\dots,U_{M}]^{\top}, Y≜∑m=1Mcm​Xm≜𝑌subscriptsuperscript𝑀𝑚1subscript𝑐𝑚subscript𝑋𝑚Y\triangleq\sum^{M}_{m=1}c_{m}X_{m}, and 𝚺X∈ℝM×Msubscript𝚺𝑋superscriptℝ𝑀𝑀\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}\!\in\!\mathbb{R}^{M\times M} satisfies [𝚺X]m1,m2=limN→∞𝔼​[(𝐠~m1N)⊤​𝐠~m2N]/Nsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝚺𝑋subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2subscript→𝑁𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptsubscript~𝐠subscript𝑚1𝑁topsuperscriptsubscript~𝐠subscript𝑚2𝑁𝑁[\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}]_{m_{1},m_{2}}\!=\!\lim_{N\rightarrow\infty}\!\mathbb{E}[(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m_{1}}^{N})\!^{\top}\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m_{2}}^{N}]/N, ∀m1,m2∈[M].for-allsubscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2delimited-[]𝑀\forall m_{1},m_{2}\in[M].

IV Aggregation Distortion Minimization

In this section, we develop an algorithm to minimize the aggregation distortion. Specifically, we first conduct a convergence analysis and show that the optimization of the convergence rate can be transformed into the problem of aggregation distortion minimization. Subsequently, we put forth an algorithm to solve the distortion minimization problem.

IV-A FL Convergence Analysis

We now conduct a convergence analysis to establish the relationship between the FL convergence rate and the aggregation distortion, i.e., the mean square error of the estimated global update. To this end, we set the local update to the model gradient with respect to the local dataset, i.e., 𝐠m(t)=∇Lm​(𝜽(t))superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑚𝑡∇subscript𝐿𝑚superscript𝜽𝑡\mathbf{g}_{m}^{(t)}=\nabla L_{m}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}), ∀m∈[M]for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\forall m\in[M], and make the following standard assumptions [13, 35]:

Assumption 2.

The global loss function L𝐿L is strongly convex with parameter ω𝜔\omega, and has Lipschitz gradient with parameter ΩΩ\Omega, i.e., for any 𝐚,𝐛∈ℝN𝐚𝐛superscriptℝ𝑁\mathbf{a},\mathbf{b}\in\mathbb{R}^{N},

L​(𝐛)≥L​(𝐚)+(𝐛−𝐚)⊤​∇L​(𝐚)+ω​‖𝐛−𝐚‖2/2𝐿𝐛𝐿𝐚superscript𝐛𝐚top∇𝐿𝐚𝜔superscriptnorm𝐛𝐚22\displaystyle L(\mathbf{b})\geq L(\mathbf{a})+\left(\mathbf{b}-\mathbf{a}\right)^{\top}\nabla L(\mathbf{a})+\omega\left\|\mathbf{b}-\mathbf{a}\right\|^{2}/2 (13)
‖∇L​(𝐛)−∇L​(𝐚)‖≤Ω​‖𝐛−𝐚‖.norm∇𝐿𝐛∇𝐿𝐚Ωnorm𝐛𝐚\displaystyle\|\nabla L(\mathbf{b})-\nabla L(\mathbf{a})\|\leq\Omega\|\mathbf{b}-\mathbf{a}\|. (14)

Proposition 3 gives a characterization of the FL convergence performance.

Proposition 3.

Under Assumption 2, consider 𝐠m(t)=∇Lm​(𝛉(t))superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑚𝑡∇subscript𝐿𝑚superscript𝛉𝑡\mathbf{g}_{m}^{(t)}=\nabla L_{m}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}), ∀m∈[M]for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\forall m\in[M], and set the learning rate η=1/Ω𝜂1Ω\eta=1/\Omega. After T𝑇T communication rounds,

L​(𝜽(T+1))−L​(𝜽⋆)≤(1−ωΩ)T+1​[L​(𝜽(0))−L​(𝜽⋆)]+N2​Ω​∑t=0T(1−ωΩ)T−t​D(t),𝐿superscript𝜽𝑇1𝐿superscript𝜽⋆superscript1𝜔Ω𝑇1delimited-[]𝐿superscript𝜽0𝐿superscript𝜽⋆𝑁2Ωsuperscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇superscript1𝜔Ω𝑇𝑡superscript𝐷𝑡\displaystyle L(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(T+1)})-L(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star})\leq\left(1-\frac{\omega}{\Omega}\right)^{T+1}\left[L(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(0)})-L(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star})\right]+\frac{N}{2\Omega}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\left(1-\frac{\omega}{\Omega}\right)^{T-t}D^{(t)}, (15)

where D(t)superscript𝐷𝑡D^{(t)} denotes the aggregation distortion at the t𝑡t-th round.

Proof.

See Appendix B. ∎

IV-B Problem Formulation

The upper bound in Proposition 3 is a monotonically increasing function of each D(t)superscript𝐷𝑡D^{(t)}, implying that we can potentially improve the FL convergence performance by separately minimizing each D(t)superscript𝐷𝑡D^{(t)}. Recall that any rate-distortion tuple in ℛ​𝒟inℛsubscript𝒟in\mathcal{RD}_{\mathrm{in}} is achievable. Thus the problem reduces to finding a rate-distortion tuple in ℛ​𝒟inℛsubscript𝒟in\mathcal{RD}_{\mathrm{in}} that minimizes the distortion D(t)superscript𝐷𝑡D^{(t)}. However, there are two pending issues:

  • (i)

    ℛ​𝒟inℛsubscript𝒟in\mathcal{RD}_{\mathrm{in}} is intractable due to the arbitrariness of the choice of (U1,…,UM)subscript𝑈1…subscript𝑈𝑀(U_{1},\dots,U_{M}) and Y^​(⋅)^𝑌⋅\hat{Y}(\cdot);

  • (ii)

    The rates in the rate-distortion tuples are chosen to satisfy the bit constraints of the FL uplinks.

In what follows, we first give a tractable inner region of ℛ​𝒟inℛsubscript𝒟in\mathcal{RD}_{\mathrm{in}} in Subsection IV-B1, and then formulate an aggregation distortion minimization problem with link budget constraints in Subsection IV-B2.

IV-B1 A tractable inner region of ℛ​𝒟inℛsubscript𝒟in\mathcal{RD}_{\mathrm{in}}

We give a tractable inner region of ℛ​𝒟inℛsubscript𝒟in\mathcal{RD}_{\mathrm{in}} by picking M𝑀M parameterized auxiliary random variables and a specific reconstruction function for ℛ​𝒟inℛsubscript𝒟in\mathcal{RD}_{\mathrm{in}}. For Gaussian equivalent sources {Xm}m=1Msubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝑚𝑀𝑚1\{X_{m}\}^{M}_{m=1}, setting the auxiliary variables to be Gaussian is a common choice [25, 22, 23]. Specifically, we define mutually independent random variables {Vm∼𝒩​(0,qm)}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsimilar-tosubscript𝑉𝑚𝒩0subscript𝑞𝑚𝑚1𝑀\{V_{m}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,q_{m})\}_{m=1}^{M} independent of {Xm}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑋𝑚𝑚1𝑀\{X_{m}\}_{m=1}^{M}. Then we set the auxiliary random variable

Um=Xm+Vm,m∈[M].formulae-sequencesubscript𝑈𝑚subscript𝑋𝑚subscript𝑉𝑚𝑚delimited-[]𝑀U_{m}=X_{m}+V_{m},\,m\in[M]. (16)

Since the quadratic distortion measure is considered, we set the reconstruction function as the minimum mean squared error (MMSE) estimator, i.e.,

Y^​(𝐮)=𝔼​[Y∣𝐮]=𝐜⊤​𝚺X​(𝚺X+𝚺V)−1​𝐮,^𝑌𝐮𝔼delimited-[]conditional𝑌𝐮superscript𝐜topsubscript𝚺𝑋superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑋subscript𝚺𝑉1𝐮\hat{Y}(\mathbf{u})=\mathbb{E}\left[Y\mid\mathbf{u}\right]=\mathbf{c}^{\top}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}+\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V})^{-1}\mathbf{u}, (17)

where 𝐜≜[c1,…,cM]⊤≜𝐜superscriptsubscript𝑐1…subscript𝑐𝑀top\mathbf{c}\triangleq[c_{1},\dots,c_{M}]^{\top} and 𝚺V≜diag​(𝐪)≜subscript𝚺𝑉diag𝐪\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}\triangleq\mathrm{diag}(\mathbf{q}), 𝐪≜[q1,…,qM]⊤≜𝐪superscriptsubscript𝑞1…subscript𝑞𝑀top\mathbf{q}\triangleq[q_{1},\dots,q_{M}]^{\top}. Then, we derive closed form expressions of I​(𝐱𝒮;𝐮𝒮∣𝐮𝒮c)𝐼superscript𝐱𝒮conditionalsuperscript𝐮𝒮superscript𝐮superscript𝒮𝑐I\left(\mathbf{x}^{\mathcal{S}};\,\mathbf{u}^{\mathcal{S}}\mid\mathbf{u}^{\mathcal{S}^{c}}\right), I​(𝐱;𝐮)𝐼𝐱𝐮I\left(\mathbf{x};\,\mathbf{u}\right) and 𝔼​[(Y−Y^​(𝐮))2]𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑌^𝑌𝐮2\mathbb{E}[(Y-\hat{Y}(\mathbf{u}))^{2}] to obtain an inner region of ℛ​𝒟inℛsubscript𝒟in\mathcal{RD}_{\textrm{in}}:

ℛ𝒟inG=⋃𝐪∈ℝ+M{\displaystyle\mathcal{RD}_{\mathrm{in}}^{\mathrm{G}}=\bigcup\limits_{\mathbf{q}\in\mathbb{R}^{M}_{+}}\bigg{\{} (R1,…,RM,D):∑m∈𝒮Rm≥I​(𝐱𝒮;𝐮𝒮∣𝐮𝒮c),∀𝒮⊂[M],𝒮≠Ø;:subscript𝑅1…subscript𝑅𝑀𝐷formulae-sequencesubscript𝑚𝒮subscript𝑅𝑚𝐼superscript𝐱𝒮conditionalsuperscript𝐮𝒮superscript𝐮superscript𝒮𝑐formulae-sequencefor-all𝒮delimited-[]𝑀𝒮italic-Ø\displaystyle(R_{1},\dots,R_{M},D):\ \sum_{m\in\mathcal{S}}R_{m}\geq I\left(\mathbf{x}^{\mathcal{S}};\,\mathbf{u}^{\mathcal{S}}\mid\mathbf{u}^{\mathcal{S}^{c}}\right),\ \forall\mathcal{S}\subset[M],\,\mathcal{S}\neq\O;

I​(𝐱𝒮;𝐮𝒮∣𝐮𝒮c)=12​log⁡(det(𝚺X+𝚺V)det(𝚺X𝒮c+𝚺V𝒮c)​det(𝚺V𝒮)),∀𝒮⊂[M],𝒮≠Ø,formulae-sequence𝐼superscript𝐱𝒮conditionalsuperscript𝐮𝒮superscript𝐮superscript𝒮𝑐12subscript𝚺𝑋subscript𝚺𝑉superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑋superscript𝒮𝑐superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑉superscript𝒮𝑐superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑉𝒮formulae-sequencefor-all𝒮delimited-[]𝑀𝒮italic-Ø\displaystyle I\left(\mathbf{x}^{\mathcal{S}};\,\mathbf{u}^{\mathcal{S}}\mid\mathbf{u}^{\mathcal{S}^{c}}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\log\left(\frac{\det\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}+\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}\right)}{\det\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}^{\mathcal{S}^{c}}+\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}^{\mathcal{S}^{c}}\right)\det\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}^{\mathcal{S}}\right)}\right),\forall\mathcal{S}\subset[M],\,\mathcal{S}\neq\O, (19)

(21)

We emphasize that ℛ​𝒟inG⊂ℛ​𝒟inℛsuperscriptsubscript𝒟inGℛsubscript𝒟in\mathcal{RD}_{\mathrm{in}}^{\mathrm{G}}\subset\mathcal{RD}_{\textrm{in}} for general 𝚺Xsubscript𝚺𝑋\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X} and 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c}. Since different choices of 𝐪𝐪\mathbf{q} lead to different codebooks of MBTC, we term 𝐪𝐪\mathbf{q} MBTC parameters.

IV-B2 Optimization problem formulation

We now formulate an optimization problem to search the rate-distortion tuple in ℛ​𝒟inGℛsuperscriptsubscript𝒟inG\mathcal{RD}_{\mathrm{in}}^{\mathrm{G}} with minimum distortion D𝐷D. From (IV-B1), for given MBTC parameters, the minimum distortion is given by v​(𝐪)𝑣𝐪v(\mathbf{q}). Thus the problem reduces to finding a minimal v​(𝐪)𝑣𝐪v(\mathbf{q}) in ℛ​𝒟inGℛsuperscriptsubscript𝒟inG\mathcal{RD}_{\mathrm{in}}^{\mathrm{G}} by tuning the MBTC parameters 𝐪𝐪\mathbf{q}.

As mentioned before, 𝐪𝐪\mathbf{q} cannot be arbitrarily chosen due to the link bit constraints. Let rmt​o​tsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑚𝑡𝑜𝑡r_{m}^{tot} denote the maximum number of total bits that device m𝑚m can transmit to the PS. To ensure reliable uplink transmission, the (source coding) rates in (IV-B1) need to satisfy

Rm≤rm,∀m∈[M],formulae-sequencesubscript𝑅𝑚subscript𝑟𝑚for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀R_{m}\leq r_{m},\ \forall m\in[M], (22)

where rm≜rmt​o​t/N≜subscript𝑟𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑚𝑡𝑜𝑡𝑁r_{m}\triangleq r_{m}^{tot}/N. Combining (IV-B1), (21), (22) and the above discussion, the distortion minimization problem is formulated as

max𝐪subscript𝐪\displaystyle\max_{\mathbf{q}}\quad 𝐜⊤​𝚺X​(𝚺X+𝚺V)−1​𝚺X⊤​𝐜superscript𝐜topsubscript𝚺𝑋superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑋subscript𝚺𝑉1superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑋top𝐜\displaystyle\mathbf{c}^{\top}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}+\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}\right)^{-1}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}^{\top}\mathbf{c} (23a)
s.t.formulae-sequencest\displaystyle\mathrm{s.t.}\quad I​(𝐱𝒮;𝐮𝒮∣𝐮𝒮c)≤∑m∈𝒮rm,∀𝒮⊂[M],𝒮≠Ø,formulae-sequence𝐼superscript𝐱𝒮conditionalsuperscript𝐮𝒮superscript𝐮superscript𝒮𝑐subscript𝑚𝒮subscript𝑟𝑚formulae-sequencefor-all𝒮delimited-[]𝑀𝒮italic-Ø\displaystyle I\left(\mathbf{x}^{\mathcal{S}};\,\mathbf{u}^{\mathcal{S}}\mid\mathbf{u}^{\mathcal{S}^{c}}\right)\leq\sum_{m\in\mathcal{S}}r_{m},\ \forall\mathcal{S}\subset[M],\ \mathcal{S}\neq\O, (23b)

IV-C MBTC Optimization Algorithm

In this subsection, we propose an iterative algorithm based on majorization-minimization (MM) to solve problem (23). Our algorithm starts with a feasible point called the current-point. Each iteration round consists of two steps. In the first step, we construct a surrogate problem, whose objective serves as a lower bound of the original objective with equality holds at the current-point. Besides, the feasible region of the surrogate problem should be a subset of the original feasible region and contains the current-point. In the second step, we solve the surrogate problem, and the solution will be used as the current-point in the next iteration.

Before proceeding, we present two lemmas for constructing the surrogate problem. Specifically, Lemma 1 helps find a lower bound of the original objective (23a), and Lemma 2 helps find a subset of the original feasible region.

Lemma 1 [36, Theorem 2].

For any 𝐚,𝐛∈ℝM𝐚𝐛superscriptℝ𝑀\mathbf{a},\mathbf{b}\in\mathbb{R}^{M} and positive definite matrix 𝐁∈ℝM×M𝐁superscriptℝ𝑀𝑀\mathbf{B}\in\mathbb{R}^{M\times M},

𝐚⊤​𝐁−1​𝐚≥2​𝐚⊤​𝐛−𝐛⊤​𝐁𝐛,superscript𝐚topsuperscript𝐁1𝐚2superscript𝐚top𝐛superscript𝐛top𝐁𝐛\mathbf{a}^{\top}\mathbf{B}^{-1}\mathbf{a}\geq 2\mathbf{a}^{\top}\mathbf{b}-\mathbf{b}^{\top}\mathbf{B}\mathbf{b}, (24)

where the equality holds when 𝐚𝐚\mathbf{a}, 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} and 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B} satisfy 𝐛=𝐁−1​𝐚𝐛superscript𝐁1𝐚\mathbf{b}=\mathbf{B}^{-1}\mathbf{a}.

Proof.

𝐚⊤​𝐁−1​𝐚≥𝐚⊤​𝐁−1​𝐚−(𝐛−𝐁−1​𝐚)⊤​𝐁​(𝐛−𝐁−1​𝐚)=2​𝐚⊤​𝐛−𝐛⊤​𝐁𝐛superscript𝐚topsuperscript𝐁1𝐚superscript𝐚topsuperscript𝐁1𝐚superscript𝐛superscript𝐁1𝐚top𝐁𝐛superscript𝐁1𝐚2superscript𝐚top𝐛superscript𝐛top𝐁𝐛\mathbf{a}^{\top}\mathbf{B}^{-1}\mathbf{a}\geq\mathbf{a}^{\top}\mathbf{B}^{-1}\mathbf{a}-(\mathbf{b}-\mathbf{B}^{-1}\mathbf{a})^{\top}\mathbf{B}(\mathbf{b}-\mathbf{B}^{-1}\mathbf{a})=2\mathbf{a}^{\top}\mathbf{b}-\mathbf{b}^{\top}\mathbf{B}\mathbf{b}, where the equality holds when 𝐛=𝐁−1​𝐚𝐛superscript𝐁1𝐚\mathbf{b}=\mathbf{B}^{-1}\mathbf{a}. ∎

According to Lemma 1, (31a) is a lower bound of (23a) with the equality holds when 𝚺V=𝚺^Vsubscript𝚺𝑉subscript^𝚺𝑉\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{V}. From Lemma 2, the feasible region of (23) contains the feasible region of (31) and both of them contain the point 𝚺V=𝚺^Vsubscript𝚺𝑉subscript^𝚺𝑉\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{V}. Thus (31) is a surrogate problem of (23) and point 𝚺V=𝚺^Vsubscript𝚺𝑉subscript^𝚺𝑉\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{V} is the current-point.

It is not difficult to verify that (31a) is a linear function of 𝐪𝐪\mathbf{q}, and both χ𝒮​(𝐄𝒮,𝐅𝒮,𝚺V)subscript𝜒𝒮subscript𝐄𝒮subscript𝐅𝒮subscript𝚺𝑉\chi_{\mathcal{S}}(\mathbf{E}_{\mathcal{S}},\mathbf{F}_{\mathcal{S}},\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}) and χ[M]​(𝐆,𝚺V)subscript𝜒delimited-[]𝑀𝐆subscript𝚺𝑉\chi_{[M]}(\mathbf{G},\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}) are convex functions of 𝐪𝐪\mathbf{q}. Thus the surrogate problem (31) is convex and can be solved optimally with existing convex optimization solvers such as CVXPY [37]. By repeatedly constructing and solving this surrogate problem following the MM framework introduced before, we can finally obtain a suboptimal solution to the original problem (23). We summarize the proposed MM-based algorithm as Algorithm 1. This algorithm converges since the objective value of the original problem (23) monotonically non-decreasing in the iterative process.

Note that problem (31) has 2M−1superscript2𝑀12^{M}-1 constraints (inherited from problem (23)), which increases exponentially with the device number M𝑀M. Thus, when considering FL systems with a relatively large number of devices, Algorithm 1 becomes computationally prohibitive. In the next section, under some symmetry assumptions, we show that problem (23) can be reformulated into a form with much fewer constraints, allowing the development of more efficient algorithms.

V Aggregation Distortion Minimization Under Symmetric Assumptions

In this section, we recast problem (23) into a form with far fewer constraints under certain symmetry assumptions, and then develop an optimization algorithm to solve it.

V-A Problem Formulation under Symmetry Assumptions

The discussion in this section is based on the following three symmetry assumptions.

Assumption 3.

The FL system is symmetric in the following senses:

  1. (i)

    Symmetry of sources: The covariance matrix 𝚺X=ρ​σX2​𝟏𝟏⊤+(σX2−ρ​σX2)​𝐈subscript𝚺𝑋𝜌superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑋2superscript11topsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑋2𝜌superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑋2𝐈\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}=\rho\sigma_{X}^{2}\mathbf{1}\mathbf{1}^{\top}+(\sigma_{X}^{2}-\rho\sigma_{X}^{2})\mathbf{I};

  2. (ii)

    Symmetry of target coefficients: 𝐜=λ⋅𝟏𝐜⋅𝜆1\mathbf{c}=\lambda\cdot\mathbf{1} with λ≠0𝜆0\lambda\neq 0;

  3. (iii)

    Symmetry of bit-constraints: All devices are divided into J𝐽J groups {𝒢j⊂[M]}j=1Jsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒢𝑗delimited-[]𝑀𝐽𝑗1\{\mathcal{G}_{j}\subset[M]\}^{J}_{j=1}, and the devices in each group have the same bit-constraint, i.e., rm=r(j)subscript𝑟𝑚subscript𝑟𝑗r_{m}=r_{(j)}, ∀m∈𝒢jfor-all𝑚subscript𝒢𝑗\forall m\in\mathcal{G}_{j}, j∈[J]𝑗delimited-[]𝐽j\in[J].

We first justify these assumptions. When data is i.i.d. among the devices and all devices have similar sample sizes, Assumption 3-(i) approximately holds, as shown in Fig. 444 of [20]. Assumption 3-(ii) can be satisfied by simply adjusting the aggregation target function.111111For instance, when considering the function κ​(𝐠1N,…,𝐠MN)=∑m=1MKm​𝐠mN/K𝜅superscriptsubscript𝐠1𝑁…superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑀𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝐾𝑚superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑚𝑁𝐾\kappa(\mathbf{g}_{1}^{N},\dots,\mathbf{g}_{M}^{N})=\sum_{m=1}^{M}K_{m}\mathbf{g}_{m}^{N}/K, Assumption 3-(ii) can be satisfied by adjusting the sample size Kmsubscript𝐾𝑚K_{m} of every device to be the same. Assumption 3-(iii) is also not difficult to satisfy since devices with loose bit-constraints can accommodate devices with tighter bit-constraints by reducing the number of transmitted bits.

We next recast problem (23) under Assumption 3. It can be verified that under Assumption 3, problem (23) is symmetric with respect to the optimization variables in the same group (defined in Assumption 3-(iii)). Thus the optimal solution of problem (23), {qmopt}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚opt𝑚1𝑀\{q_{m}^{\mathrm{opt}}\}_{m=1}^{M}, satisfies qmopt=q(j)optsubscriptsuperscript𝑞opt𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗optq^{\mathrm{opt}}_{m}=q_{(j)}^{\mathrm{opt}}, ∀m∈𝒢j,j∈[J]formulae-sequencefor-all𝑚subscript𝒢𝑗𝑗delimited-[]𝐽\forall m\in\mathcal{G}_{j},\,j\in[J]. V-B MBTC Optimization Algorithm Under Symmetry Assumptions

We now develop an MM-based algorithm to solve problem (33). Specifically, to construct a surrogate problem, we need to find a lower bound of the objective (33a) and an upper bound of function ϑitalic-ϑ\vartheta. Note that functions log⁡(1+a/x)1𝑎𝑥\log(1+a/x), a≥0𝑎0a\geq 0, x>0𝑥0x\textgreater 0 and log⁡(1+∑j=1Jaj/(b+xj))1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐽subscript𝑎𝑗𝑏subscript𝑥𝑗\log(1+\sum_{j=1}^{J}a_{j}/(b+x_{j})), b≥0𝑏0b\geq 0, aj≥0subscript𝑎𝑗0a_{j}\geq 0, xj>0subscript𝑥𝑗0x_{j}\textgreater 0, ∀j∈[J]for-all𝑗delimited-[]𝐽\forall j\in[J], are both convex. Thus an appropriate upper bound of function ϑitalic-ϑ\vartheta can be obtained by expanding its third term as its first-order Taylor polynomial. Specifically, given a feasible point {q^(j)}j=1Jsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript^𝑞𝑗𝑗1𝐽\{\hat{q}_{(j)}\}_{j=1}^{J}, we have

(36b)

Since ϑup​({q(j)}j=1J;{ςj}j=1J)superscriptitalic-ϑupsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗𝑗1𝐽superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜍𝑗𝑗1𝐽\vartheta^{\text{up}}\left(\{q_{(j)}\}_{j=1}^{J};\{\varsigma_{j}\}_{j=1}^{J}\right) is convex, problem (36) is convex and can be solved optimally by existing convex optimization solvers such as CVXOPT [38]. Again, by repeatedly constructing and solving this surrogate problem, we can finally obtain a suboptimal solution to problem (33). We summarize this algorithm as Algorithm 2. This algorithm converges since the objective value of problem (33) is monotonically non-decreasing in the iterative process.

Problem (36) has ∏j=1J(Mj+1)−1superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗1𝐽subscript𝑀𝑗11\prod_{j=1}^{J}(M_{j}+1)-1 constraints, with growth rate much slower than that of (31), which is 2M−1superscript2𝑀12^{M}-1. Thus Algorithm 2 can be used to optimize the MBTC parameters for larger-scale FL systems. Clearly, the choice of group number J𝐽J gives rise to a trade-off between the computational complexity for solving (36) and the system performance. Specifically, if J=1𝐽1J=1, problem (36) has only M𝑀M constraints. This greatly reduces the computational complexity compare with Algorithm 1, but may severely sacrifice the aggregation accuracy in order to satisfy Assumption 3-(iii). As J𝐽J approaches M𝑀M, the computational complexity gradually catches up with that of problem (23), while the degradation of aggregation accuracy also diminishes. In practice, we can flexibly determine the value of J𝐽J as needed.

VI Numerical Results

In this section, we first introduce the method to numerically evaluate the limits of FL convergence performance, then reveal the gap between the baseline schemes and our theoretical bound in terms of aggregation distortion, convergence performance, and communication cost.

VI-A FL Convergence Performance Evaluation

Note that the solution 𝐪∗superscript𝐪\mathbf{q}^{*} obtained by solving problem (23) not only corresponds to a point in ℛ​𝒟inGℛsuperscriptsubscript𝒟inG\mathcal{RD}_{\mathrm{in}}^{\mathrm{G}} with small distortion, but also implies a codebook generation method for our achievability scheme. At each iteration round t𝑡t, we can apply our achievability scheme with the 𝐪∗superscript𝐪\mathbf{q}^{*}-codebook to compute 𝐠^(t)superscript^𝐠𝑡\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{(t)} and then use it to update the global model. In this way, the FL convergence performance limits (in the sense of the performance limits of model aggregation) can be numerically evaluated. In the following, we detail the convergence performance evaluation method.

Recall that the FL training follows the four steps in Subsection II-A. Since the steps (i), (ii), and (iv) are straightforward, we focus on the model aggregation step, i.e., how to compute 𝐠^Nsuperscript^𝐠𝑁\hat{\mathbf{g}}^{N} using {𝐠mN}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑚𝑁𝑚1𝑀\{\mathbf{g}_{m}^{N}\}_{m=1}^{M}. Specifically, given the local updates {𝐠mN}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑚𝑁𝑚1𝑀\{\mathbf{g}_{m}^{N}\}_{m=1}^{M} at iteration round t𝑡t, we first compute {𝐱mN}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑚𝑁𝑚1𝑀\{\mathbf{x}_{m}^{N}\}_{m=1}^{M} using (7) and (8)121212In the simulation, as an approximation to the random rotation step (8), we divide each vector 𝐠~mNsuperscriptsubscript~𝐠𝑚𝑁\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m}^{N} into segments with a length of 102410241024 and then generate Haar matrices to multiply the segments (the remaining segment with less than 102410241024 elements is multiplied by a Haar matrix with the corresponding dimension).. Then, we follow Section IV-B1 for the encoding and decoding of MBTC. Specifically, to calculate the output of the decoder, we first approximate 𝚺Xsubscript𝚺𝑋\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X} by [𝚺X]m1,m2≈(𝐠~m1N)⊤​𝐠~m2N/Nsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝚺𝑋subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript~𝐠subscript𝑚1𝑁topsuperscriptsubscript~𝐠subscript𝑚2𝑁𝑁[\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}]_{m_{1},m_{2}}\approx(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m_{1}}^{N})^{\top}\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{m_{2}}^{N}/N, ∀m1,m2∈[M]for-allsubscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2delimited-[]𝑀\forall m_{1},m_{2}\in[M], then solve problem (23) to obtain the MBTC parameters 𝐪∗=[q1∗,…,qM∗]⊤superscript𝐪superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑞1…superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑀top\mathbf{q}^{*}=[q_{1}^{*},\dots,q_{M}^{*}]^{\top}. Denoting 𝚺V∗≜diag​(𝐪∗)≜superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑉diagsuperscript𝐪\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}^{*}\triangleq\mathrm{diag}(\mathbf{q}^{*}), we combine (16) and (17) to calculate the output of the decoder as

=n𝐜⊤𝚺X(𝚺X+𝚺V∗)−1[[𝐱1N+𝐯1N]n,…,[𝐱MN+𝐯MN]n]⊤,∀n∈[N],\displaystyle{}_{n}=\mathbf{c}^{\top}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}+\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}^{*})^{-1}\left[[\mathbf{x}_{1}^{N}+\mathbf{v}_{1}^{N}]_{n},\dots,[\mathbf{x}_{M}^{N}+\mathbf{v}_{M}^{N}]_{n}\right]^{\top},\,\forall n\in[N], (37)

VI-B Aggregation Distortion Comparison

In this subsection, the baseline schemes are compared (using synthetic data) with our bound in terms of the aggregation distortion with fixed source coding (quantization) rate R𝑅R, i.e., the number of encoded (quantized) bits per source symbol. The baselines include QSGD [15], uniform quantization with random rotation [26], two-dimensional UVeQFed [18], nested quantization followed by entropy coding131313Since the nested quantization scheme in [31] uses one-dimensional nested lattices to implement the lattice-based Wyner–Ziv coding scheme in [39], it cannot be guaranteed to decode successfully. We slightly improve the nested quantization scheme in [31] in the simulation: when the scheme cannot decode successfully, re-transmit. [31].

The synthetic data is generated as follows. Let 𝐬∈ℝN𝐬superscriptℝ𝑁\mathbf{s}\in\mathbb{R}^{N} and {𝐰m∈ℝN}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚superscriptℝ𝑁𝑚1𝑀\{\mathbf{w}_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{N}\}_{m=1}^{M} be mutually independent random vectors with i.i.d. standard Gaussian elements. Given ρ∈[0,1]𝜌01\rho\in[0,1], the synthetic data to be encoded/quantized is then given by 𝐲m=ρ​𝐬+1−ρ​𝐰msubscript𝐲𝑚𝜌𝐬1𝜌subscript𝐰𝑚\mathbf{y}_{m}=\sqrt{\rho}\mathbf{s}+\sqrt{1-\rho}\mathbf{w}_{m}, ∀m∈[M]for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\forall m\in[M]. Note that 𝐲msubscript𝐲𝑚\mathbf{y}_{m} also has i.i.d. standard Gaussian elements, ∀m∈[M]for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\forall m\in[M], and the correlation coefficient of [𝐲m1]nsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐲subscript𝑚1𝑛[\mathbf{y}_{m_{1}}]_{n} and [𝐲m2]nsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐲subscript𝑚2𝑛[\mathbf{y}_{m_{2}}]_{n} is exactly ρ𝜌\rho, ∀n∈[N]for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\forall n\in[N], m1≠m2∈[M]subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2delimited-[]𝑀m_{1}\neq m_{2}\in[M]. Thus we can adjust the correlation between {𝐲m}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐲𝑚𝑚1𝑀\{\mathbf{y}_{m}\}_{m=1}^{M} by adjusting ρ𝜌\rho. The target is to recover the aggregated vector 𝐲≜∑m=1M𝐲m/M≜𝐲superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝐲𝑚𝑀\mathbf{y}\triangleq\sum_{m=1}^{M}\mathbf{y}_{m}/M.

As discussed in Section III, our MBTC-based achievability scheme allows separate encoding on each 𝐲msubscript𝐲𝑚\mathbf{y}_{m} and joint decoding to directly obtain 𝐲^^𝐲\hat{\mathbf{y}} (an estimation of 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y}). For the baselines, we separately quantize 𝐲msubscript𝐲𝑚\mathbf{y}_{m} into 𝐲^msubscript^𝐲𝑚\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{m} using the corresponding quantization schemes with rate-determined quantization resolutions, and then obtain 𝐲^^𝐲\hat{\mathbf{y}} by

𝐲^=∑m=1M𝐲^m/M.^𝐲superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript^𝐲𝑚𝑀\hat{\mathbf{y}}=\sum_{m=1}^{M}\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{m}/M. (38)

The distortion is measured by the average squared error ‖𝐲−𝐲^‖2/Nsuperscriptnorm𝐲^𝐲2𝑁\|\mathbf{y}-\hat{\mathbf{y}}\|^{2}/N. In the simulation, we set the number of samples N=217𝑁superscript217N=2^{17} and the number of sources M=10𝑀10M=10.

In Fig. 3, we plot the average squared error versus the coding (quantization) rate with different values of ρ𝜌\rho. As expected, the baselines are far from our bound when the correlation coefficient ρ𝜌\rho is large, suggesting that the baselines have great potential for further improvement when the sources (local updates) are strongly correlated. Note that the baselines are consistently worse than our bound, even when ρ=0𝜌0\rho=0. This is due to the fact that our bound is essentially obtained by infinite-length vector quantization.

VI-C FL Performance Comparison

In this subsection, we compare the baselines with our bound in terms of the convergence performance and the communication cost. To this aim, we test our achievability scheme and the baselines by training a convolutional neural network (CNN), illustrated by Fig. 4, in an FL fashion on the MNIST and the Fashion-MNIST datasets. The baselines include BSC [40], top-k sparsification with residual accumulation [41], DPCM followed by entropy coding141414The scheme “DPCM followed by entropy coding” treats each local update as a sample sequence drawn from a source with memory and then encodes the sequence using first-order differential pulse code modulation (DPCM), where the predictor weights are calculated statistically., and the baselines considered in the previous subsection151515We do not consider scheme “Random rotation + uniform quantization” for comparison since it is inapplicable for the settings of Fig. 5.. We uniformly allocate the data of the training dataset to the devices and ensure the data allocated to each device is identically distributed. Within each training round, each device uses its local data to train an epoch of five stochastic gradient descent (SGD) iterations with learning rate η=0.1𝜂0.1\eta=0.1. The local update is obtained by calculating the difference between the model parameters before and after the local training. Besides, we adopt a linear aggregation target function κ​(x1,…,xM)=∑m=1MKm​xm/K𝜅subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝐾𝑚subscript𝑥𝑚𝐾\kappa(x_{1},\dots,x_{M})=\sum_{m=1}^{M}K_{m}x_{m}/K. The FL parameters are summarized in TABLE I.

VI-C1 Convergence performance comparison

In this part, we compare the FL convergence performance of different schemes with identical coding (quantization) rate. We consider a wireless FL uplink for simulation. The system consists of one single-antenna PS and M𝑀M single-antenna devices, where the devices are randomly distributed inside a circle centered on the PS with radius d𝑑d. For the uplink channels, we consider the Rayleigh fading model and the 5G Urban Macro (UMa) pathloss model given by European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI) [42]. The channels are assumed to be unchanged during a communication round. For each device m𝑚m, we assume that its uplink information rate can reach its channel capacity Cmsubscript𝐶𝑚C_{m}, m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M]. Further, we assume that each device performs ΥΥ\Upsilon times of channel realizations in each communication round. Then the maximum source coding (quantization) rate rmsubscript𝑟𝑚r_{m} of device m𝑚m can be calculated by rm=Υ​Cm/Nsubscript𝑟𝑚Υsubscript𝐶𝑚𝑁r_{m}=\Upsilon C_{m}/N, ∀m∈[M]for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\forall m\in[M], where N=86546𝑁86546N=86546 according to the CNN structure. At each round, each scheme is adjusted to meet the maximum coding (quantization) rate constraints. Specifically, our achievability schemes can naturally meet these maximum rate constraints since they appear as constraints of problem (23). As for the baselines, we adjust their quantization resolutions to meet these constraints, and adopt (38) for aggregation. In the simulation, we set M=8𝑀8M=8, d=1.5𝑑1.5d=1.5 km, the power of additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) as −8080-80 dBm, the devices’ transmitting power as 555 dBm, the height of the PS antenna as 252525 m, the height of the device antennas as 1.51.51.5 m, and the center frequency as 755755755 MHz.

Fig. 5 plots the FL convergence performance of the considered schemes under MNIST and Fashion-MNIST datasets with the value of channel use times ΥΥ\Upsilon adopted as 1.5×1081.5superscript1081.5\times 10^{8}, 7.5×1087.5superscript1087.5\times 10^{8}, and 1.5×1091.5superscript1091.5\times 10^{9}, respectively. It is worth emphasizing that when ΥΥ\Upsilon takes 1.5×1081.5superscript1081.5\times 10^{8}, 7.5×1087.5superscript1087.5\times 10^{8}, and 1.5×1091.5superscript1091.5\times 10^{9}, each local update element is quantized on average to 0.6030.6030.603 bits, 3.0153.0153.015 bits, and 6.0306.0306.030 bits, respectively. For the “Our bound with symmetry assumptions” case, we divide the eight devices into four groups in pairs such that the devices in the same group have relatively closer bit-constraints. For each group, we make the bit-constraints of both devices to be the same by tightening the looser one, which is always realizable. Besides, we assume that Assumption 3-(i) holds. The above settings and assumption allow us to tune the MBTC parameters using Algorithm 2. For the error free case, the local updates are aggregated without quantization. As shown in Fig. 5, with the increase of the number of bits allowed to be transmitted in each round (realized by the increase of ΥΥ\Upsilon), the convergence rate and the final convergence point of every scheme increases. Further, we observe that our bounds are close to the error-free case, providing a promising convergence performance. Besides, we observe that the performance loss brought by devices grouping is negligible. This implies that, when the symmetry assumptions are satisfied, the grouping method is promising to reduce the complexity of coding parameters optimization with slight performance penalty.

VI-C2 Communication cost comparison

In this part, we compare the minimum source coding (quantization) rates required to achieve given convergence performances. We consider a fully symmetric FL system for simulation. Specifically, we assume that Assumptions 3-(i) and -(ii) hold and consider all the devices share the same source coding (quantization) rate. We set the number of devices M=20𝑀20M=20 and the source coding (quantization) rate R=rt​o​t/N𝑅superscript𝑟𝑡𝑜𝑡𝑁R=r^{tot}/N, where the number of symbols N=86546𝑁86546N=86546 according to the CNN structure. In the simulation, we increase rt​o​tsuperscript𝑟𝑡𝑜𝑡r^{tot} initialized to a sufficiently small positive number with 100100100-bit increment repeatedly until the classification accuracy at the 100100100-th communication round is greater than a preset value. TABLE II records this first-arrival rate for different schemes under different preset accuracies and datasets. We see that, to achieve a certain accuracy, the rates required by the baselines are all much greater than that needed by our achievability scheme (which leads to our bound).

We now summarize the qualitative analysis of the numerical results in this section. Our bound is a “good” achievable bound mainly due to the following three properties of our proposed achievability scheme: 1) exploit the correlation between local updates for compression; 2) perform joint decoding at PS to directly reconstruct the global update, i.e., a linear combination of the local updates; 3) use infinite-length vector quantization. Due to 1), the baselines in Fig. 3 deviate farther and farther away from our bound as the data correlation increases; due to 3), the baselines in Fig. 3 are consistently worse than our bound, even if the data are completely uncorrelated. Properties 1) and 2) allow the re-allocation of the communication demands among devices by utilizing the correlation between local updates, thereby reducing the number of bits that need to be transmitted by deep-fading devices, explaining the “good” performance of our bound in Fig. 5. The results in TABLE II are mainly due to properties 1) and 3) since, under the considered fully symmetric simulation setup, the baseline’s aggregation scheme (i.e., first decoding separately and then arithmetically averaging) is efficient enough.

VII Conclusion

In this paper, we studied the FL uplink from an information-theoretic perspective. We introduced a general performance analysis framework for model aggregation. We then characterized the performance limits of model aggregation in the form of an inner region of the rate-distortion region. Further, we developed two algorithms to search for the minimum aggregation distortion in the derived inner region for general and symmetric FL systems, respectively. Numerical results demonstrated that the baseline model aggregation schemes still have great potential for further improvement in the considered scenarios.

as N→∞→𝑁N\to\infty. Thus, we approximately have ‖𝐞(t)‖2≤N​D(t)superscriptnormsuperscript𝐞𝑡2𝑁superscript𝐷𝑡\|\mathbf{e}^{(t)}\|^{2}\leq ND^{(t)}. Combining with (49), we obtain (15).

In the same way, we obtain an upper bound of I​(𝐱;𝐮)𝐼𝐱𝐮I(\mathbf{x};\,\mathbf{u}):

Appendix D Problem Transformation

We first consider the objective of problem (32). According to Assumptions 3-(i) and -(ii), we have

𝚺X⊤​𝐜=((M−1)​ρ+1)​λ​σX2⋅𝟏.superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑋top𝐜⋅𝑀1𝜌1𝜆superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑋21\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}^{\top}\mathbf{c}=((M-1)\rho+1)\lambda\sigma_{X}^{2}\cdot\mathbf{1}. (60)

Let 𝚺t​e​m​p=(𝚺V+(1−ρ)​σX2​𝐈)−1subscript𝚺𝑡𝑒𝑚𝑝superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑉1𝜌superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑋2𝐈1\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{temp}=(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}+(1-\rho)\sigma_{X}^{2}\mathbf{I})^{-1}. According to the Sherman–Morrison formula, we have

(𝚺X+𝚺V)−1=𝚺t​e​m​p−ρ​σX2​𝚺t​e​m​p​𝟏𝟏⊤​𝚺t​e​m​p1+ρ​σX2​𝟏⊤​𝚺t​e​m​p​𝟏.superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑋subscript𝚺𝑉1subscript𝚺𝑡𝑒𝑚𝑝𝜌superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑋2subscript𝚺𝑡𝑒𝑚𝑝superscript11topsubscript𝚺𝑡𝑒𝑚𝑝1𝜌superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑋2superscript1topsubscript𝚺𝑡𝑒𝑚𝑝1(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}+\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V})^{-1}=\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{temp}-\frac{\rho\sigma_{X}^{2}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{temp}\mathbf{1}\mathbf{1}^{\top}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{temp}}{1+\rho\sigma_{X}^{2}\mathbf{1}^{\top}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{temp}\mathbf{1}}. (61)

Together, the objective function of problem (32) can be rewritten as

𝐜⊤​𝚺X​(𝚺X+𝚺V)−1​𝚺X⊤​𝐜=[((M−1)​ρ+1)​λ​σX2]2/(1𝟏⊤​𝚺t​e​m​p​𝟏+ρ​σX2).superscript𝐜topsubscript𝚺𝑋superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑋subscript𝚺𝑉1superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑋top𝐜superscriptdelimited-[]𝑀1𝜌1𝜆superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑋221superscript1topsubscript𝚺𝑡𝑒𝑚𝑝1𝜌superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑋2\displaystyle\mathbf{c}^{\top}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}+\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V})^{-1}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}^{\top}\mathbf{c}=\left[((M-1)\rho+1)\lambda\sigma_{X}^{2}\right]^{2}\bigg{/}\left(\frac{1}{\mathbf{1}^{\top}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{temp}\mathbf{1}}+\rho\sigma_{X}^{2}\right). (62)

To maximize (62) by tuning {q(j)}j=1Jsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗𝑗1𝐽\{q_{(j)}\}_{j=1}^{J}, we only need to maximize 𝟏⊤​𝚺t​e​m​p​𝟏superscript1topsubscript𝚺𝑡𝑒𝑚𝑝1\mathbf{1}^{\top}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{temp}\mathbf{1}, which equals to ∑j=1JMj/(q(j)+(1−ρ)​σX2)superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐽subscript𝑀𝑗subscript𝑞𝑗1𝜌superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑋2\sum_{j=1}^{J}M_{j}/(q_{(j)}+(1-\rho)\sigma_{X}^{2}) according to (32c). This gives the objective of problem (33).

We then consider the constraints of problem (32). Since constraint (32c) is simple variable substitutions, we focus on constraint (32b). From (19) and (20), constraint (32b) is given by

I​(𝐱𝒮;𝐮𝒮∣𝐮𝒮c)=12​log⁡(det(𝚺X+𝚺V)det(𝚺X𝒮c+𝚺V𝒮c)​det(𝚺V𝒮))≤∑m∈𝒮rm,∀𝒮⊂[M],𝒮≠Ø,formulae-sequence𝐼superscript𝐱𝒮conditionalsuperscript𝐮𝒮superscript𝐮superscript𝒮𝑐12subscript𝚺𝑋subscript𝚺𝑉superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑋superscript𝒮𝑐superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑉superscript𝒮𝑐superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑉𝒮subscript𝑚𝒮subscript𝑟𝑚formulae-sequencefor-all𝒮delimited-[]𝑀𝒮italic-Ø\displaystyle I\left(\mathbf{x}^{\mathcal{S}};\,\mathbf{u}^{\mathcal{S}}\mid\mathbf{u}^{\mathcal{S}^{c}}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\log\left(\frac{\det\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}+\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}\right)}{\det\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}^{\mathcal{S}^{c}}+\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}^{\mathcal{S}^{c}}\right)\det\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}^{\mathcal{S}}\right)}\right)\leq\sum_{m\in\mathcal{S}}r_{m},\forall\mathcal{S}\subset[M],\,\mathcal{S}\neq\O, (63)
I​(𝐱;𝐮)=12​log⁡(det(𝚺X+𝚺V)det(𝚺V))≤∑m∈[M]rm.𝐼𝐱𝐮12subscript𝚺𝑋subscript𝚺𝑉subscript𝚺𝑉subscript𝑚delimited-[]𝑀subscript𝑟𝑚I\left(\mathbf{x};\,\mathbf{u}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\log\left(\frac{\det\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}+\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}\right)}{\det\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}\right)}\right)\leq\sum_{m\in[M]}r_{m}. (64)

Further transformation relies on the following key observation. Given nonempty sets 𝒮1,𝒮2⊂[M]subscript𝒮1subscript𝒮2delimited-[]𝑀\mathcal{S}_{1},\,\mathcal{S}_{2}\subset[M] satisfy |𝒮1|=|𝒮2|subscript𝒮1subscript𝒮2|\mathcal{S}_{1}|=|\mathcal{S}_{2}|. If the elements in sets 𝒮1subscript𝒮1\mathcal{S}_{1} and 𝒮2subscript𝒮2\mathcal{S}_{2} are clustered in the same way (i.e., the number of elements assigned to each group is the same), the two constraints corresponding to these two sets have exactly the same form, i.e., they degenerate into one constraint. This inspires us to distinguish constraints by the number of devices selected (by a set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}) in each group. Specifically, let ςj∈{0}∪[Mj]subscript𝜍𝑗0delimited-[]subscript𝑀𝑗\varsigma_{j}\in\{0\}\cup[M_{j}] denote the number of devices selected (by a set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}) in group j𝑗j, ∀j∈[J]for-all𝑗delimited-[]𝐽\forall j\in[J]. Note that for a matrix 𝐀=b⋅𝟏𝟏⊤+diag​([a1,…,aM])𝐀⋅𝑏superscript11topdiagsubscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎𝑀\mathbf{A}=b\cdot\mathbf{1}\mathbf{1}^{\top}+\mathrm{diag}([a_{1},\dots,a_{M}]), its determinant det(𝐀)=(1+∑m=1M\mathrm{det}(\mathbf{A})=(1+\sum_{m=1}^{M} b/am)∏m=1Mamb/a_{m})\prod_{m=1}^{M}a_{m}. Thus for any set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} satisfying |{s|s∈groupj,s∈𝒮}|=ςjconditional-set𝑠formulae-sequence𝑠subscriptgroup𝑗𝑠𝒮subscript𝜍𝑗|\{s|s\in\mathrm{group}_{j},\,s\in\mathcal{S}\}|=\varsigma_{j}, ∀j∈[J]for-all𝑗delimited-[]𝐽\forall j\in[J], we have

det(𝚺V𝒮)=∏j=1Jq(j)ςj,superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑉𝒮superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗1𝐽superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗subscript𝜍𝑗\det\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}^{\mathcal{S}}\right)=\prod_{j=1}^{J}q_{(j)}^{\varsigma_{j}}, (65)
det(𝚺X𝒮c+𝚺V𝒮c)=(1+∑j=1J(Mj−ςj)​ρ​σX2(1−ρ)​σX2+q(j))​∏j=1J[(1−ρ)​σX2+q(j)]Mj−ςj.superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑋superscript𝒮𝑐superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑉superscript𝒮𝑐1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐽subscript𝑀𝑗subscript𝜍𝑗𝜌superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑋21𝜌superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑋2subscript𝑞𝑗superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗1𝐽superscriptdelimited-[]1𝜌superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑋2subscript𝑞𝑗subscript𝑀𝑗subscript𝜍𝑗\displaystyle\det\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{X}^{\mathcal{S}^{c}}+\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}^{\mathcal{S}^{c}}\right)=\left(1+\sum_{j=1}^{J}\frac{(M_{j}-\varsigma_{j})\rho\sigma_{X}^{2}}{(1-\rho)\sigma_{X}^{2}+q_{(j)}}\right)\prod_{j=1}^{J}[(1-\rho)\sigma_{X}^{2}+q_{(j)}]^{M_{j}-\varsigma_{j}}. (66)

Similarly,

det(𝚺V)=∏j=1Jq(j)Mj,subscript𝚺𝑉superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗1𝐽superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗subscript𝑀𝑗\det\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{V}\right)=\prod_{j=1}^{J}q_{(j)}^{M_{j}}, (67)

Substituting (65)-(68) into (63) and (64), we obtain the left-hand side of (33b). The right-hand side of (33b) can be directly obtained according to Assumption 3-(iii).
